title: Understanding DNS
content: This episode focuses on understanding DNS, including the foundational principles and how it relates to human motor development.

title: Common injuries and issues
content: Michael also shares the most common injuries and issues he sees in patients in his practice, such as postural problems and back pain, and how the movements of a DNS program are used to avoid injury, maintain longevity, and improve sports performance.

title: Foundational principles of DNS
content: The Prague School of Rehabilitation, and functional rehabilitation as the foundation of the dynamic neuromuscular stabilization (DNS) program (5:00); Foundational principles of DNS, and the role of the diaphragm in muscular stability (19:00); Types of muscle contractions (28:15); Human motor development through the lens of DNS, and when issues begin to arise (32:30); DNS for injuries, pain, pre-habilitation, and performance enhancement (1:03:45); Etiology of back pain (1:10:00); The Prague School curriculum: 3 tracks for certification in DNS (1:20:45);

title: Common postural syndromes
content: Common postural syndromes (50:00); Increasing functional threshold to minimize time in the functional gap (56:45);

title: The Impact of Stress on Physical and Emotional Health
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., discusses the widespread impact of stress on our physical and emotional health as well as the mechanisms by which it can precipitate chronic illness, dementia, depression, and more.

title: Physiology of a stress response
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., discusses the widespread impact of stress on our physical and emotional health as well as the mechanisms by which it can precipitate chronic illness, dementia, depression, and more. He also provides insight into the factors that contribute to the stress response (and our ability to handle it) such as social rank, personality, environment, and genetics.

title: Individual variation in the response to stress
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., discusses the individual variation in the response to stress, and how everyone has a different optimal level. He also talks about how social rank and personality differences affect our stress response.

title: Tips for managing stress in the modern world
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., provides tips for managing stress in the modern world.

title: The impact of stress on cancer, atherosclerosis, dementia, addiction, and depression
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., discusses the impact of stress on cancer, atherosclerosis, dementia, addiction, and depression.

title: Michael's background in sports medicine and rehabilitation
content: Michael is a chiropractor based in San Diego who specializes in rehabilitation sports medicine. He is part of the sports medicine team for PGA Tour and the World Surf League Tour and is on the USA Surfing Performance Committee.

title: The Prague School of Rehabilitation and DNS
content: DNS is based on functional rehabilitation and was pioneered by three Prague School neurologists, Vladimir Janda, Karel Lewit, and Václav Vojta. The Prague School of Rehabilitation was founded in the 1950s at Charles University in Prague in the Czech Republic. Pavel Kolář currently runs the rehabilitation department at Prague School.

title: Postural habituation and its effects on the body
content: Postural habituation is when a specific musculature tends towards tightness while other musculature tends towards weakness. Upper cross syndrome affects the neck and shoulder region, causing neck muscles to tighten and other musculature in the upper extremity to weaken. Lower cross syndrome affects the lower back and hip region, causing the hip flexor complex to be overactive and tightened while the lower abdominal region and the gluteal region become weak and inhibited. These imbalances lead to overload in specific areas of the kinematic chain, causing repetitive stresses on the passive structures within the chain.

title: Prague School of Rehabilitation
content: The Prague School of Rehabilitation was founded by three doctors, Janda, Lewit, and Vojta. They developed specific treatments involving both exercise and manual maneuvers. Janda had post-polio type syndrome, which was likely a motivation for his passion for observing movement and rehabilitation. Lewit specifically focused on joint and soft tissue dysfunction in relation to upper and lower cross syndromes. Vojta observed the development of motor function after birth during the first 12 months when the postural foundations are established neurologically. The focus was on treatment of cerebral palsy.

title: Pavel Kolář
content: Pavel Kolář is the head of the Prague School of Rehabilitation and head clinician for the Czech Olympic Teams and Czech National Sports Teams. He himself was a high-level Olympic level gymnast and also a pediatric physiotherapist. The idea is that the central nervous system is key to facilitating the efficiency of transfer of load throughout that kinematic chain. He started to apply that base of knowledge to injured athletes around late 90s /early 2000s. He helped rehabilitate Jan Železný, Olympic javelin thrower, and Jaromír Jágr, Czech hockey player. He integrated the concepts and principles of dynamic neuromuscular stabilization to decrease the risk of reinjury and provide the potential for better performance.

title: Foundational principles of DNS, and the role of the diaphragm in muscular stability
content: DNS stands for Dynamic Neuromuscular Stabilization. It is the connection between the nervous system (primarily central) and the muscular system. Using developmental kinesiology as a way to explain posture and dynamic stabilization. The diaphragm is a dome-shaped striated muscle with a non-muscular component. It has attachments on the lower six ribs on the back of the xiphoid process (bone at the end of the sternum) and on the L1, L2 vertebra. One of the primary functions is respiration. The CNS has not matured enough to create a fixed point through the trunk and the pelvis.

title: The Diaphragm and Abdominal Wall Musculature
content: Around 3 months, hard-wired, genetically-ingrained motor functions kick in and start to see this coordinated activity of that deep group of muscles. Peter suggests thinking of the diaphragm like a cylinder. The strongest cylinder would have a big top, a big bottom, and symmetrical sides. The diaphragm is like the top of that cylinder. The bottom of the cylinder is the pelvic floor, whose musculature will coordinate the regulation of intra-abdominal pressure that is created with the descending of the diaphragm. Besides respiration, the diaphragm has a postural function. Creates intra-abdominal pressure and the pelvic floor is active and stretches (eccentric loading). Abdominal wall musculature: rectus abdominis (six-pack muscles), oblique musculature that crosses the body, comes up and attaches to the rib cage, Transverse abdominis: wraps around from the back. Diaphragm descends, performs a stabilization function, creates intra-abdominal pressure that musculature reacts to. Eccentric contraction followed by an isometric contraction. But body must coordinate between the respiratory and postural functions. CNS needs to generate enough pressure to maintain stability but also allow the diaphragm to descend enough for lungs to expand. If this coordination is not working well, see overutilization / lower crossed syndrome and lose deep stabilization. Brain uses compensatory pattern to maintain stability.

title: Types of Muscle Contractions
content: Types of muscle contractions [28:15]. Concentrically loaded: when a muscle getting shorter as it’s being loaded. Eccentrically loaded: when a muscle is getting longer as it’s being loaded. When training, most people tend to emphasize the concentric and don’t realize the eccentric. Too much emphasis on the eccentric will create more hypertrophy. But with, for example, hip abduction, eccentric control is a very important part of injury prevention. What these pioneers (Vojta, Janda, Lewit, Kolář) noticed was the importance of training that central nervous system to optimize stabilization, stereotype, and synergy. Then get what Kolář calls centration throughout that chain of movement / kinematic chain. For example, good hip joint stability requires a nice interplay between agonist and antagonist, between concentric and eccentric activity. Need to maintain an ideal position of the femur and the acetabulum for full range of motion. If that is compromised throughout any part of that kinematic chain, it’s going to affect the quality of centration (transfer of force) and load above and below that region.

title: Human Motor Development through the Lens of DNS
content: Prague School’s assessment and treatment is focused on the quality of synergy, coordination and timing of deep stabilization. Based on developmental kinesiology, which is the neurophysiological aspects of the maturing locomotor system. Human motor development through the lens of DNS, and when issues begin to arise [32:30]. 3 months can create fixed point so now the larger muscle groups have something to anchor off of; can turn head and fix gaze. Can lift legs out of base of support. Triple flexion: 90 degrees at the hip, 90 degrees at the knee, neutral position of the ankle joint or subtalar joint. Can bring their hands together and bring their hands to their mouth.

title: Developmental Milestones and the Prague School Approach
content: The Prague School approach tries to assess the efficiency of the deep stabilization system and uses specific active exercises based on developmental milestones. At 3 months, infants start to have the ability to stabilize along the sagittal plane. By 4-4.5 months, fixed point coordination is usually complete, and they start to be able to utilize the oblique slings. As management of intra-abdominal pressure improves, hips and legs into higher position, range of reach improves, and they can reach the groin area. At 5 months, they reach their knees, and at 6 months, they reach their feet. At 7 months, they bring foot to mouth.

title: Postural Syndromes
content: Kids sitting in chairs 6-7 hours a day when they go to school is where you see the beginning of postural syndromes. Ideally, keep alignment of the pelvic floor and thoracic diaphragm.

title: Efficient Alignment and Intra-Abdominal Pressure
content: The more efficiently we keep this alignment, the more efficiently we manage intra-abdominal pressure and uprighting throughout the spine, and the transfer of force and load. With DNS, regain intra-abdominal pressure through eccentric loading of the “cylinder” rather than concentric loading. Kids develop via an “inside out” strategy, intra-abdominal pressure to load abdominal wall, interplay of concentric, eccentric, isometric activity to manage that pressure.

title: Postural Habituation and Accessory Breathing Musculature
content: If we fall into repetitive posturals or postural habituation, which [in our] society is kind of a bit prevalent, gravity is going to win. Start to fall into slumping posture, shoulders come forward, inhibit diaphragm descending that we need for respiration and stabilization, accessory breathing musculature kicks in (sternocleidomastoid, upper trapezius, scalenes – which attach to your cervical spine and the upper two ribs – and pectoralis minor). If we do it often enough, it becomes our default pattern to decrease utilization of full expansion of the diaphragm and over-utilize the accessory breathing musculature.

title: Functional Threshold and Quality of Stabilization
content: Increasing quality of dynamic stabilization is what happens developmentally. Increasing functional threshold to minimize time in the functional gap. Top athletes have full extension, rotation, and flexion. Bracing also provides stability. Athletes have strong postural foundations, cortical function, and body awareness; can both relax and stabilize in different areas. Functional gap: when go beyond the functional threshold to maintain quality of stabilization. Athletes train for this because always pushing the threshold. High threshold compensatory pattern starts to become the norm with training. One goal is to help people improve quality of stabilization so they can increase ability to stay within functional threshold.

title: Elite Athletes and Injury Prevention
content: Peter thinks many elite athletes don’t have to formally train in DNS because they do it naturally. One of the hallmarks of [athletic] greatness is injury prevention. It’s not just the greatness at what they do, it’s the longevity with which they can do it. Roger Federer is an example of an athlete with longevity and quick recovery from injuries. Železný had a 20 year career in javelin. Jágr still playing hockey at 48. Athletes with good training programs and coaches tend to stay within functional capacity.

title: DNS for Injuries, Pain, Pre-habilitation, and Performance Enhancement
content: Peter imagines two ends of the spectrum with patients: Have injury and go back to figure out what they were doing wrong to teach them how to stabilize muscles correctly. Seeking performance enhancement. Michael says most of his patients come for pain and injury. Integrating exercises based off of developmental milestones. Once they have improved, work with trainer or coach for strength training and specific technique.

title: Focus on quality of stabilization, movement, and transfer of force and load
content: once they’re out of pain, focus on quality of stabilization, movement, and transfer of force and load

title: DNS rehab plan and its usage
content: Only 10-20% of Michael’s patients end up following DNS rehab plan long term DNS is starting to be used in some places, like in major league baseball

title: Importance of integrating quality of movement and stability
content: In the west, we are focused on stats (lift, strength capacity, etc.) but also need to integrate the quality of movement and stability and then strength thresholds

title: Prehabilitation program after pain improves
content: After pain improves, use prehabilitation program Have them practice certain sequences of movements and exercises to improve stability

title: Most common complaint in his office is low back pain
content: Most common complaint in his office is low back pain

title: Etiology of back pain
content: Peter says 80% of people experience back pain at some point, so very important to understand the etiology Unless caused by an injury like an accident or fall, it’s mostly chronic overload over time

title: Skeletal anatomy
content: The sacrum is a single bone (other bones fused over time) Five lumbar discs numbered one through five disc between each of those lumbar vertebral bodies (for example, L4 is the disc between vertebrae three and four) disc between the L5 and the sacrum is S1 vertebral bodies held in place by the discs, the facet joints that run behind them the lamina, which are longer bones, hold it together but don’t provide support like the facet joints and at the disc interface

title: Musculature scaffolding that provides stabilization and uprighting effect
content: Also musculature scaffolding that provides stabilization and uprighting effect muscles attached to the anterior (front) of vertebral bodies:psoas, which attaches to those transverse (side) processes of the lumbar spinequadratus lumborum is also attached to those processes

title: Tendency for overactivation of extensor and flexor
content: Tendency for overactivation of extensor and flexor (psoas)

title: Stress fracture in his back led Michael to the Prague School
content: How a stress fracture in his back led Michael to the Prague School [1:16:00]

title: DNS Curriculum
content: The DNS curriculum has three tracks for certification: Clinical track, D course, and a course for both trainers and clinicians. DNS also has specialty courses. DNS can be easily integrated into existing training programs.

title: Challenges for Patients
content: DNS may be less effective because people don’t stay with it once out of pain. DNS requires practice and is not a quick fix. DNS is most effective for those who buy into the philosophy.

title: Expertise within Prague School
content: The Prague School has expertise in running, dance, golf, baseball, hockey, lifting, and strength. Specialty courses help with integration and communication about a specific sport.

title: Exercise Videos
content: The exercise videos cover diaphragmatic breathing and the postural function of the diaphragm.

title: Lesson 1: Stabilization and Breathing
content: Lie on back with knees bent, feet on ground. Can facilitate this function by: breathing in, feeling diaphragm descending and abdominal wall expansion. Load pelvic floor, responds eccentrically. Then see management of eccentric, concentric, and isometric contraction. Maintain this stabilization and fixed point while also breathing. Not sticking out belly, muscles should lift: eccentric loading of entire abdominal wall. Feel activation on sides and back as well as front. Thoracic-lumbar junction is key. Challenge coordination of respiratory and postural function: Lift ball overhead without scissoring of thoracic cage and pelvic floor. Hold ball while also lifting and then and lowering leg, maintaining connection. Lift ball overhead while keeping both legs up.

title: Lesson 3: Activation of stabilizing function
content: 3 month developmental position. Start getting sagittal stability. Infant can prop up on elbows, look from side to side. But CNS not yet developed enough to be able to lift the arm out of support. Face down with elbows in line with ear canal. Cue stabilizing function with breath. Expansion of abdominal wall. Uprighting through cervical spine. Fixed point through shoulder girdle, trunk and pelvis. By 4.5-5 months, can use leg as contralateral support. This contralateral pattern is what you see with runners. If runner can’t find stability, start here. Issues around the thoracic-abdominal junction are common. If one area is not efficient, it affects whole chain.

title: Lesson 4: Five-month developmental position
content: Infant can turn to side at 5 months. If line up properly: Get stable point for oblique slings. Centrated position in shoulder girdle. Facilitates uprighting through cervical spine. By 6 months, turn onto belly. 7 months, low oblique sitting position (first time trunk of out of support position in frontal plane). Integration of stabilization and transfer force/load into daily life. Can get impingement syndrome if lack stability.

title: Lesson 5: Developmental flow in prone position
content: Month-by-month development. Show how to work through sequences of developmental positions maintaining stabilizing function and finding ideal points of support. “Postural tai chi”. Centration, stabilization, and differentiation of extremities. Training CNS to get better stability and can then integrate into any activity.

title: Lesson 6: Bear flow progression
content: Higher developmental sequence. Hands-and-knee position. Bring hips above shoulder (about 12 months). Infants now have hand and foot support. Use Core 360 belt. Can put in nubs areas where seeing inefficient facilitation of eccentric loading. Gives proprioceptive feedback (not weight belt or support belt). Lower knees to mat (and then come up) without losing stabilizing function. Challenges: lift one leg, raise one arm to the ceiling while maintaining stabilizing function. Even very strong people might have trouble. Shows that their connection may not be efficient. Can’t transfer power well without overloading transitional areas throughout kinematic chain.

title: Lesson 7: Hip mobility stability flow
content: Progression from 7.5-8 months (high oblique sit) to 10-11 months and then a standing position. Oblique sit to single-leg lunge to standing without needing arm support. Stability of trunk and pelvis, positioning force and load through lower extremity, need acetabulum to be able to more the right way around the head of the femur. If don’t do it the right way, knees and lower back will be overloaded. One of Peter’s “Centenarian Decathlon” points is being able to get off the ground without using his hands. Can be modified if have pain or need to gradually work up to it. With consistency and repetition, develop a motor engram and becomes the default. In reverse it’s eccentric stretching of glutes and leg muscles. Not the same as a “shin box” stretch – it’s not “crunching your cylinder” but instead bending and folding at the waist.

title: Lesson 8: Developmental sequence under load
content: Weight helps you feel the stabilizing function as go through the developmental sequences. Good for athletes – combines stability, mobility, and load. Only use as much weight as allows you to still maintain your functional threshold, ideal centration and stabilization. Provides a challenge which reinforces the pattern. Can then integrate it into other sports.
